newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccans vote Friday on changing constitution.
newsitem.headline: Moroccans vote Friday on changing constitution.

text.p: After weeks of political party activity, millions of Moroccans are to vote on Friday on change to their 1992 constitution which would set up a powerful second house of parliament.

Last minute appeals for the more than 12 million eligible Moroccans to vote "yes" dominated the media on Thursday, after pro-government and opposition parties alike almost unanimously urged their supporters to back King Hassan's proposals.
The king, whose paramount powers will not be touched, said the change would split the present 333-seat Majlis Anuwab (Chamber of Representatives) into two to strengthen regional representation.
The second house, indirectly elected mainly through local councils, professional bodies and trade unions, will have power to force a vote of no-confidence in the government.
"It is very rare for a second chamber to have such power," one Western diplomat commented.
"On balance, what the new constitution does allow -- though I don't expect this for some time -- is more democracy if the authorities decide not to interfere (in the indirect elections)."
The official news agency MAP said the new house, the Majlis al-Mustasharin (Consultative Chamber), would be elected for nine years but renew one-third of members each three years.

The lower house, now with one-third of its members elected indirectly, will be elected directly. The opposition, with more than one-third of present MPs, has long called for total direct elections to the existing parliament.
Morocco's main opposition parties, the old-guard Istiqlal party with 52 seats, and Socialist Union of People's Forces (USFP) with 56 seats, have, despite reservations, called for a "yes" vote.
"Our 'yes' vote will enable the country to get out of the political impasse and the wait and see situation," Mohamed Guessous, a leading USFP figure said earlier this week.

And one senior Moroccan official, commenting on the 'yes' call, said: "It should be noted that this is the first time that there is a general consensus and a positive approach on constitution reforms proposed by the royal palace since 1961."

Several small parties have, however, called either for a boycott or a 'no' vote. And on Wednesday, the Avant-Garde Democratic and Socialist Party said police had arrested five of its members while they campaigned for a boycott.
The Interior Ministry said it was not aware of the arrests.

Another party, the Democratic Organisation of Peoples' Action, with two seats in parliament, said in its mouthpiece Anwal on Thursday: "The constitution (changes) do not take account of genuine public opinion and...will keep citizens far from taking political decisions."
The employment ministry has called on employers to ensure everyone has chance to vote.
Another constitutional change will set up a watchdog to oversee the budget -- seen as vital to help spread development to the countryside.
In a recent report, drawn up with the United Nations, Rabat drew a bleak picture of rural life -- high female illiteracy, children absent from schools, little drinking water, poverty.
Moroccans registered for the referendum include more than 118,000 people in the disputed Western Sahara.
Voting stations open at 8 a.m. (0800 gmt) and are due to close at 6 p.m. (1800 GMT). First results are expected around 10 p.m., with final results on Saturday. REUTER JFB/BA
